importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the attempted assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico in Handlova, Slovakia, where Juraj Cintula shot at him, marking a pivotal moment in national political tension.
The date of the court verdict sentencing Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison, concluding a lengthy trial and reinforcing concerns about political violence in Slovakia.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from May 2024 to October 2025 represents the timeline of the assassination attempt, legal proceedings, and public reaction, highlighting a critical phase in Slovak political and social life.

keyTakeAways: Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker, stonemason, writer, and public activist, was found guilty of terrorism charges and sentenced to 21 years in prison for shooting Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024.

Cintula shot at Fico five times from a distance of just over one meter during a public greeting in Handlova, leaving Fico with serious injuries including abdominal wounds and damage to his hip, hand, and foot.

The Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica ruled that the attack constituted terrorism, not just murder or an attack on a public official, citing that Cintula specifically targeted the prime minister.
Cintula claimed he wanted to harm Fico, not kill him, because he opposed Fico's policies on Ukraine, media freedom, and cultural policies, which he said threatened Slovak freedom and society.

The verdict has intensified political divisions in Slovakia, with Fico blaming the opposition for societal anger, while the opposition accuses him of undermining democracy, media freedom, and covering up corruption.
The court acknowledged Cintula's stated motive—expressing opposition to political policies—but still classified the act as terrorism due to its targeted nature and political intent.
Fico, who has remained in public life despite ongoing health issues, has expressed forgiveness toward Cintula.
Cintula has announced plans to appeal the verdict, calling it 'unjust'.
The case underscores the deep political and social polarization in Slovakia, with violence becoming a symbol of ideological conflict between populism and liberal democracy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court has sentenced Juraj Cintula, a 72-year-old former mine worker and public activist, to 21 years in prison for attempting to assassinate Prime Minister Robert Fico in May 2024 during a public event in Handlova. Cintula shot at Fico five times from within one meter, seriously injuring him. The Specialized Criminal Court in Banska Bystrica ruled that the attack constituted terrorism due to its targeted nature, even though Cintula stated he did not intend to kill. The verdict reflects deep societal and political divisions in Slovakia, with Fico blaming opposition forces for societal anger and the opposition accusing him of undermining democratic values. Cintula has expressed intent to appeal the verdict, calling it unjust. The case has highlighted tensions over political freedom, media control, and foreign policy, particularly concerning Ukraine and Moscow relations, and underscores the broader risk of political violence in democratic societies.
title: Slovakia Court Sentences Suspect in Attempted Assassination of Prime Minister Robert Fico to 21 Years
